The Master is focused on analyzing (science), manipulating (technology) and developing (engineering) structures at the nanometer scale. A multidisciplinary scientific education is offered, integrating nanophysics, nanochemistry, nanomaterials science, nanoelectronics engineering, nanobioscience engineering and quantum engineering, to empower students in creating novel nanodevices and nanomaterials and incorporate them in useful products.

schedule 120 ECTS
language Fully taught in English, also available in Dutch
account_balance Faculty of Engineering Science
Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering, newborn scientific disciplines, are situated at the interface of physics, chemistry, materials science, electronics, biotechnology and quantum engineering. Not only does the nanometer scale allow for a higher density of impactful nanodevices and nanostructures, but it is also the scale, at which the assembly of atoms and molecules into structures determines their electrical, optical, magnetic, thermal and mechanical properties. You will learn the basics of these disciplines at the nanometer scale and the use of nanotechnologies for devices and materials at the macro scale. You decide on a particular scientific focus, as the programme consists of 4 options.
The programme is both strongly application-and research-oriented, and is closely linked to the research centres of global leaders such as imec and the Leuven NanoCentre.
The nanosciences are multidisciplinary. Special courses are designed to encourage thinking beyond the boundaries of the individual scientific disciplines. The courses are continuously updated following the latest innovations in this young and highly innovative field.
The teaching staff in the programme is closely affiliated with cutting-edge research centres like imec and the Leuven NanoCentre, which are considered worldwide leaders in the domain of nanoscience and nanotechnology. The programme therefore has an important research-oriented flavor, and is simultaneously strongly application oriented, with focus on relevant problems in the field, through the strong links of the research centres with industrial partners. In your master’s thesis, you will have the opportunity to work in the exciting research programmes of these institutes.
At the Faculty of Engineering Science, students are given the opportunity to complete one or two semesters abroad within the Erasmus+ programme at a European university or a university outside of Europe, or to take a one-week intensive course (Athens week) at another European university.
The programme consists of  several course categories, each with their own purpose:
The programme culminates in the master's thesis research project.
You can also elect to follow a similar interuniversity programme, the Erasmus Mundus master of Science in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, whereby the first master year is spent at KU Leuven, while the second master year takes place at a partnering university abroad.
Your programme
The Faculty of Engineering Science at KU Leuven is involved in several Erasmus exchange programmes. For the Master of Nanoscience, this means that you can complete one or two semesters abroad, at a number of selected universities.
Going abroad
The Faculty of Engineering Science offers two types of internships in all its master’s programmes: Industrial Experience and Industrial Internships.
Internships in nanoscience, nanotechnology and nanoengineering
Rewatch the webinar about the Faculty of Engineering Science programmes given on 28 November 2024.
All students who did not obtain their previous degree at an institution of the Flemish Community, must submit an application via the Admissions office. Be sure to check out the specific admission requirements (diploma requirements, language requirements and possible additional requirements). The only way to know whether you can be admitted to any of our programmes is by applying and completing the application process.
Official and current admission requirements.
Applicants must both be qualified and motivated to start our master's programme in Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering.
For the most recent - and only official information - on application deadlines, check the application window for this programme.
Check the information on how to apply for this programme. There is also a video that explains the application procedure from start to finish.
It is worth noting that our tuition fees are more affordable than many other leading universities thanks to generous government financing of higher education in Belgium. The fees for any individual student are contingent upon their academic programme and the nationality of the student.
For the most recent – and only official information – on the tuition fees, check the tuition fee calculator.
KU Leuven offers a variety of scholarships for qualifying students. Just as with our tuition fees, these scholarships may be contingent on a student’s academic programme or nationality, so be sure to thoroughly check eligibility requirements before applying.
The study costs consist of the yearly tuition fee on the one hand, and degree specific costs on the other hand. Beside study costs you also need to take living and transportation expenses into account.
Companies or research institutes where nanoscale innovation is the path forward are particularly interested in our master's graduates. These companies/institutes are part of a very diverse spectrum of sectors, just like the master programme offered: our graduates can be found back in the electronics ad nanotechnology sector, in the new and smart materials sector, in the chemical technology sector, and in the biotechnology sector. They join companies or research institutes in multiple roles: as R&D researchers, product design engineers, process engineers or project responsibles, and we also see them start as independent consultants. Their mulitdisciplinary back-pack is an important asset.
Our Student Career Center and our student organisation VTK are both happy to put you on the right track towards your first work experience. They also coaches you in the search for an interesting job and help you with job interviews.
For students wanting to start their own business KU Leuven also has KICK, the KU Leuven community that encourages students with innovative and entrepreneurial ideas.
KU Leuven Kick
The Faculty of Engineering Sciences constantly aims at strengthening the contacts between alumni as well as between alumni and current students.​​​​
KU Leuven is one of Europe’s highest-ranked and most renowned universities. It boasts a long tradition of pioneering research and high-quality education. But KU Leuven has quite a few other strengths as well.
The city of Leuven is home to the main and largest KU Leuven campus.
Life at KU Leuven
This programme is organised by the Faculty of Engineering Science, located at our beautiful and green campus in Heverlee - south of Leuven.​​​​​​
Website of the Faculty of Engineering Science

About the nano programme 
Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering, newborn scientific disciplines, are situated at the interface of physics, chemistry, materials science, electronics, biotechnology and quantum engineering. Not only does the nanometer scale allow for a higher density of impactful nanodevices and nanostructures, but it is also the scale, at which the assembly of atoms and molecules into structures determines their electrical, optical, magnetic, thermal and mechanical properties. You will learn the basics of these disciplines at the nanometer scale and the use of nanotechnologies for devices and materials at the macro scale. You decide on a particular scientific focus, as the programme consists of 4 options. 
The programme is both strongly application-and research-oriented, and is closely linked to the research centres of global leaders such as imec and the Leuven NanoCentre. 
Programme strengths
The nanosciences are multidisciplinary. Special courses are designed to encourage thinking beyond the boundaries of the individual scientific disciplines. The courses are continuously updated following the latest innovations in this young and highly innovative field.
The teaching staff in the programme is closely affiliated with cutting-edge research centres like imec and the Leuven NanoCentre, which are considered worldwide leaders in the domain of nanoscience and nanotechnology. The programme therefore has an important research-oriented flavor, and is simultaneously strongly application oriented, with focus on relevant problems in the field, through the strong links of the research centres with industrial partners. In your master’s thesis, you will have the opportunity to work in the exciting research programmes of these institutes.
At the Faculty of Engineering Science, students are given the opportunity to complete one or two semesters abroad within the Erasmus+ programme at a European university or a university outside of Europe, or to take a one-week intensive course (Athens week) at another European university.

 

Programme Master of Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering
The programme consists of  several course categories, each with their own purpose:

'Fundamental' courses: students typically have a solid fundamental background, but not in all science and engineering disciplines aimed at in this nano master programme. Therefore, the 'fundamental' courses are intended to complete the student's background.
'Core' courses: the multidisciplinary essence of the nano programme
Option-specific compulsory courses: the student chooses one of the following four options,  which each have a set of specialization courses:
	
Nanomaterials and Nanochemistry
Nanophysics and Nanoelectronics engineering
Nanobiotechnology
Quantum Engineering, Materials and Technology




Technical elective courses: the student can choose amongst a long list of nano-specific elective courses, based on personal interest.
Broadening elective courses: a limited selection is made from a list of general interest courses to enhance non-technical skills

The programme culminates in the master's thesis research project.
You can also elect to follow a similar interuniversity programme, the Erasmus Mundus master of Science in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, whereby the first master year is spent at KU Leuven, while the second master year takes place at a partnering university abroad.

Admission and application


Admission requirements
All students who did not obtain their previous degree at an institution of the Flemish Community, must submit an application via the Admissions office. Be sure to check out the specific admission requirements (diploma requirements, language requirements and possible additional requirements). The only way to know whether you can be admitted to any of our programmes is by applying and completing the application process. 
Official and current admission requirements.
Student profile
Applicants must both be qualified and motivated to start our master's programme in Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering.

You have a thorough knowledge of mathematics (including advanced algebra and differential equations), physics and chemistry, and a basic knowledge of electronics and biochemistry. 
You have a strong analytical skillset, capable of understanding real-life engineering problems, of translating them into scientific mechanisms and of applying the laws of science to solve or improve them.
You are excited about fundamental sciences and technological problems and about multidisciplinary teamworld
You have a broad scientific interest and are excited about the nano world
You have a clear sense of the societal relevance of technology

Application window
For the most recent - and only official information - on application deadlines, check the application window for this programme. 
Application procedure
Check the information on how to apply for this programme. There is also a video that explains the application procedure from start to finish.  




Tuition fees


Tuition fees
It is worth noting that our tuition fees are more affordable than many other leading universities thanks to generous government financing of higher education in Belgium. The fees for any individual student are contingent upon their academic programme and the nationality of the student.  
For the most recent – and only official information – on the tuition fees, check the tuition fee calculator. 
Scholarships
KU Leuven offers a variety of scholarships for qualifying students. Just as with our tuition fees, these scholarships may be contingent on a student’s academic programme or nationality, so be sure to thoroughly check eligibility requirements before applying. 


Study costs


The study costs consist of the yearly tuition fee on the one hand, and degree specific costs on the other hand. Beside study costs you also need to take living and transportation expenses into account.

After graduation



 

Career perspectives
Companies or research institutes where nanoscale innovation is the path forward are particularly interested in our master's graduates. These companies/institutes are part of a very diverse spectrum of sectors, just like the master programme offered: our graduates can be found back in the electronics ad nanotechnology sector, in the new and smart materials sector, in the chemical technology sector, and in the biotechnology sector. They join companies or research institutes in multiple roles: as R&D researchers, product design engineers, process engineers or project responsibles, and we also see them start as independent consultants. Their mulitdisciplinary back-pack is an important asset.  






Career support
Our Student Career Center and our student organisation VTK are both happy to put you on the right track towards your first work experience. They also coaches you in the search for an interesting job and help you with job interviews.

About the nano programme 
Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering, newborn scientific disciplines, are situated at the interface of physics, chemistry, materials science, electronics, biotechnology and quantum engineering. Not only does the nanometer scale allow for a higher density of impactful nanodevices and nanostructures, but it is also the scale, at which the assembly of atoms and molecules into structures determines their electrical, optical, magnetic, thermal and mechanical properties. You will learn the basics of these disciplines at the nanometer scale and the use of nanotechnologies for devices and materials at the macro scale. You decide on a particular scientific focus, as the programme consists of 4 options. 
The programme is both strongly application-and research-oriented, and is closely linked to the research centres of global leaders such as imec and the Leuven NanoCentre. 
Programme strengths
The nanosciences are multidisciplinary. Special courses are designed to encourage thinking beyond the boundaries of the individual scientific disciplines. The courses are continuously updated following the latest innovations in this young and highly innovative field.
The teaching staff in the programme is closely affiliated with cutting-edge research centres like imec and the Leuven NanoCentre, which are considered worldwide leaders in the domain of nanoscience and nanotechnology. The programme therefore has an important research-oriented flavor, and is simultaneously strongly application oriented, with focus on relevant problems in the field, through the strong links of the research centres with industrial partners. In your master’s thesis, you will have the opportunity to work in the exciting research programmes of these institutes.
At the Faculty of Engineering Science, students are given the opportunity to complete one or two semesters abroad within the Erasmus+ programme at a European university or a university outside of Europe, or to take a one-week intensive course (Athens week) at another European university.

 

Programme Master of Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering
The programme consists of  several course categories, each with their own purpose:

'Fundamental' courses: students typically have a solid fundamental background, but not in all science and engineering disciplines aimed at in this nano master programme. Therefore, the 'fundamental' courses are intended to complete the student's background.
'Core' courses: the multidisciplinary essence of the nano programme
Option-specific compulsory courses: the student chooses one of the following four options,  which each have a set of specialization courses:
	
Nanomaterials and Nanochemistry
Nanophysics and Nanoelectronics engineering
Nanobiotechnology
Quantum Engineering, Materials and Technology




Technical elective courses: the student can choose amongst a long list of nano-specific elective courses, based on personal interest.
Broadening elective courses: a limited selection is made from a list of general interest courses to enhance non-technical skills

The programme culminates in the master's thesis research project.
You can also elect to follow a similar interuniversity programme, the Erasmus Mundus master of Science in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, whereby the first master year is spent at KU Leuven, while the second master year takes place at a partnering university abroad.
Your programme






Student exchange
The Faculty of Engineering Science at KU Leuven is involved in several Erasmus exchange programmes. For the Master of Nanoscience, this means that you can complete one or two semesters abroad, at a number of selected universities.
Going abroad






Internships
The Faculty of Engineering Science offers two types of internships in all its master’s programmes: Industrial Experience and Industrial Internships.

Admission and application


Admission requirements
All students who did not obtain their previous degree at an institution of the Flemish Community, must submit an application via the Admissions office. Be sure to check out the specific admission requirements (diploma requirements, language requirements and possible additional requirements). The only way to know whether you can be admitted to any of our programmes is by applying and completing the application process. 
Official and current admission requirements.
Student profile
Applicants must both be qualified and motivated to start our master's programme in Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering.

You have a thorough knowledge of mathematics (including advanced algebra and differential equations), physics and chemistry, and a basic knowledge of electronics and biochemistry. 
You have a strong analytical skillset, capable of understanding real-life engineering problems, of translating them into scientific mechanisms and of applying the laws of science to solve or improve them.
You are excited about fundamental sciences and technological problems and about multidisciplinary teamworld
You have a broad scientific interest and are excited about the nano world
You have a clear sense of the societal relevance of technology

Application window
For the most recent - and only official information - on application deadlines, check the application window for this programme. 
Application procedure
Check the information on how to apply for this programme. There is also a video that explains the application procedure from start to finish.  




Tuition fees


Tuition fees
It is worth noting that our tuition fees are more affordable than many other leading universities thanks to generous government financing of higher education in Belgium. The fees for any individual student are contingent upon their academic programme and the nationality of the student.  
For the most recent – and only official information – on the tuition fees, check the tuition fee calculator. 
Scholarships
KU Leuven offers a variety of scholarships for qualifying students. Just as with our tuition fees, these scholarships may be contingent on a student’s academic programme or nationality, so be sure to thoroughly check eligibility requirements before applying. 


Study costs


The study costs consist of the yearly tuition fee on the one hand, and degree specific costs on the other hand. Beside study costs you also need to take living and transportation expenses into account. 

tuition fees
specific study costs for this degree
cost of living in Belgium



After graduation



 

Career perspectives
Companies or research institutes where nanoscale innovation is the path forward are particularly interested in our master's graduates. These companies/institutes are part of a very diverse spectrum of sectors, just like the master programme offered: our graduates can be found back in the electronics ad nanotechnology sector, in the new and smart materials sector, in the chemical technology sector, and in the biotechnology sector. They join companies or research institutes in multiple roles: as R&D researchers, product design engineers, process engineers or project responsibles, and we also see them start as independent consultants. Their mulitdisciplinary back-pack is an important asset.  






Career support
Our Student Career Center and our student organisation VTK are both happy to put you on the right track towards your first work experience. They also coaches you in the search for an interesting job and help you with job interviews.

Master of Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering
The Master is focused on analyzing (science), manipulating (technology) and developing (engineering) structures at the nanometer scale. A multidisciplinary scientific education is offered, integrating nanophysics, nanochemistry, nanomaterials science, nanoelectronics engineering, nanobioscience engineering and quantum engineering, to empower students in creating novel nanodevices and nanomaterials and incorporate them in useful products. 


About the programme

Introduction to KU Leuven: webinars
[CARD]
Programme Master of Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering
The programme consists of  several course categories, each with their own purpose:

'Fundamental' courses: students typically have a solid fundamental background, but not in all science and engineering disciplines aimed at in this nano master programme. Therefore, the 'fundamental' courses are intended to complete the student's background.
'Core' courses: the multidisciplinary essence of the nano programme
Option-specific compulsory courses: the student chooses one of the following four options,  which each have a set of specialization courses:
	
Nanomaterials and Nanochemistry
Nanophysics and Nanoelectronics engineering
Nanobiotechnology
Quantum Engineering, Materials and Technology




Technical elective courses: the student can choose amongst a long list of nano-specific elective courses, based on personal interest.
Broadening elective courses: a limited selection is made from a list of general interest courses to enhance non-technical skills

The programme culminates in the master's thesis research project.
You can also elect to follow a similar interuniversity programme, the Erasmus Mundus master of Science in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, whereby the first master year is spent at KU Leuven, while the second master year takes place at a partnering university abroad.

Career perspectives
Companies or research institutes where nanoscale innovation is the path forward are particularly interested in our master's graduates. These companies/institutes are part of a very diverse spectrum of sectors, just like the master programme offered: our graduates can be found back in the electronics ad nanotechnology sector, in the new and smart materials sector, in the chemical technology sector, and in the biotechnology sector. They join companies or research institutes in multiple roles: as R&D researchers, product design engineers, process engineers or project responsibles, and we also see them start as independent consultants. Their mulitdisciplinary back-pack is an important asset.

[HEADING] Application window
Select the academic year, your nationality, and the programme of your choice to find out which application deadline applies to you.
Regardless of the deadline, we advise you to apply at your earliest convenience, as seats may fill up early for certain programmes and you may need additional time to apply for travel and study documents. To ensure your application is processed in time, we recommend you apply before:•  1 March for non-EEA citizens•  1 June for EEA citizens and non-EEA citizens with a valid Belgian residence permit 
The academic year 2025-2026 starts on 17 September 2025.

This program can be adapted according to the previous knowledge of the student.
Students take a maximum of 16 credits.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will offer the students the necessary basis to disciplines (mathematics, physics, biology and electronics) in which they have had no training during their bachelor studies and which are essential for the rest of the master.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will be determined for each incoming student, based on his/her previous education. Once the fundamental courses are selected and approved they become compulsory for the master. If the students need less than 16 credits, the remaining credits can be chosen from the broadening elective courses.
All courses are obligatory.H06N2A "Lectures on Nanoscience and Nanotechnology" is spread over two academic years. Students have to follow this course in the first programme stage, and also in the second programma stage.Important: Students have to select H06N2A via their ISP (My Studyprogramme) in the second programme stage.
The student chooses one option.
All courses are compulsory.
All courses are compulsory.
All courses are compulsory.
At least 21 ECTS out of the following courses are compulsory.
At least 21 ECTS of the following courses are compulsory.
The student chooses minimum 9 and maximum 27 credits from cluster 1-6, other than their compulsory option specific courses.
The student chooses at most one of the following courses: H0V01A or H0V02A (Capita selecta ingenieurswetenschappen: Athens).
The Master's Thesis is compulsory.
One of the three courses is compulsory.Students who already successfully completed a course with the same content before starting this programme, have to take another 3 ECTS course instead.
The student chooses at least 6 and at most 9 credits from the following list, taking into account that:- The course H04X2A (Project management) has to be taken up in the same year as the Master Thesis.- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H04B3A (Engels in de bedrijfsomgeving) or H04B4A (Frans in de bedrijfsomgeving).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H06B4A and H06U6A (Dutch Language and Culture).- Students may take maximum 9 credit points of the courses Industrial Experience, Industrial Internship, H0T39A Entrepreneurship in de praktijk/in practice and H0T91A Entrepreneurship in practice/service- learning.- Students select, with approval, at most one of the following two courses: H0T39A (Entrepreneurship in practice, 3 ECTS) and H0T91A (Entrepreneurship in practice/service-learning, 6 ECTS).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: C00M0A (Recht van de intellectuele eigendom) or G0B01A (Intellectual Property Management).

crop_square
                                        Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals
                


Students take a maximum of 16 credits.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will offer the students the necessary basis to disciplines (mathematics, physics, biology and electronics) in which they have had no training during their bachelor studies and which are essential for the rest of the master.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will be determined for each incoming student, based on his/her previous education. Once the fundamental courses are selected and approved they become compulsory for the master. If the students need less than 16 credits, the remaining credits can be chosen from the broadening elective courses.

                                        Elective Courses
                


The student chooses at least 6 and at most 9 credits from the following list, taking into account that:- The course H04X2A (Project management) has to be taken up in the same year as the Master Thesis.- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H04B3A (Engels in de bedrijfsomgeving) or H04B4A (Frans in de bedrijfsomgeving).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H06B4A and H06U6A (Dutch Language and Culture).- Students may take maximum 9 credit points of the courses Industrial Experience, Industrial Internship, H0T39A Entrepreneurship in de praktijk/in practice and H0T91A Entrepreneurship in practice/service- learning.- Students select, with approval, at most one of the following two courses: H0T39A (Entrepreneurship in practice, 3 ECTS) and H0T91A (Entrepreneurship in practice/service-learning, 6 ECTS).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: C00M0A (Recht van de intellectuele eigendom) or G0B01A (Intellectual Property Management).

                                        Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals
                


Students take a maximum of 16 credits.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will offer the students the necessary basis to disciplines (mathematics, physics, biology and electronics) in which they have had no training during their bachelor studies and which are essential for the rest of the master.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will be determined for each incoming student, based on his/her previous education. Once the fundamental courses are selected and approved they become compulsory for the master. If the students need less than 16 credits, the remaining credits can be chosen from the broadening elective courses.

                                        Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals
                


Students take a maximum of 16 credits.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will offer the students the necessary basis to disciplines (mathematics, physics, biology and electronics) in which they have had no training during their bachelor studies and which are essential for the rest of the master.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will be determined for each incoming student, based on his/her previous education. Once the fundamental courses are selected and approved they become compulsory for the master. If the students need less than 16 credits, the remaining credits can be chosen from the broadening elective courses.

                                        Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals
                


Students take a maximum of 16 credits.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will offer the students the necessary basis to disciplines (mathematics, physics, biology and electronics) in which they have had no training during their bachelor studies and which are essential for the rest of the master.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will be determined for each incoming student, based on his/her previous education. Once the fundamental courses are selected and approved they become compulsory for the master. If the students need less than 16 credits, the remaining credits can be chosen from the broadening elective courses.

The student chooses at least 6 and at most 9 credits from the following list, taking into account that:- The course H04X2A (Project management) has to be taken up in the same year as the Master Thesis.- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H04B3A (Engels in de bedrijfsomgeving) or H04B4A (Frans in de bedrijfsomgeving).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H06B4A and H06U6A (Dutch Language and Culture).- Students may take maximum 9 credit points of the courses Industrial Experience, Industrial Internship, H0T39A Entrepreneurship in de praktijk/in practice and H0T91A Entrepreneurship in practice/service- learning.- Students select, with approval, at most one of the following two courses: H0T39A (Entrepreneurship in practice, 3 ECTS) and H0T91A (Entrepreneurship in practice/service-learning, 6 ECTS).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: C00M0A (Recht van de intellectuele eigendom) or G0B01A (Intellectual Property Management).

                                        Elective Courses
                


The student chooses at least 6 and at most 9 credits from the following list, taking into account that:- The course H04X2A (Project management) has to be taken up in the same year as the Master Thesis.- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H04B3A (Engels in de bedrijfsomgeving) or H04B4A (Frans in de bedrijfsomgeving).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H06B4A and H06U6A (Dutch Language and Culture).- Students may take maximum 9 credit points of the courses Industrial Experience, Industrial Internship, H0T39A Entrepreneurship in de praktijk/in practice and H0T91A Entrepreneurship in practice/service- learning.- Students select, with approval, at most one of the following two courses: H0T39A (Entrepreneurship in practice, 3 ECTS) and H0T91A (Entrepreneurship in practice/service-learning, 6 ECTS).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: C00M0A (Recht van de intellectuele eigendom) or G0B01A (Intellectual Property Management).

                                        Elective Courses
                


The student chooses at least 6 and at most 9 credits from the following list, taking into account that:- The course H04X2A (Project management) has to be taken up in the same year as the Master Thesis.- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H04B3A (Engels in de bedrijfsomgeving) or H04B4A (Frans in de bedrijfsomgeving).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H06B4A and H06U6A (Dutch Language and Culture).- Students may take maximum 9 credit points of the courses Industrial Experience, Industrial Internship, H0T39A Entrepreneurship in de praktijk/in practice and H0T91A Entrepreneurship in practice/service- learning.- Students select, with approval, at most one of the following two courses: H0T39A (Entrepreneurship in practice, 3 ECTS) and H0T91A (Entrepreneurship in practice/service-learning, 6 ECTS).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: C00M0A (Recht van de intellectuele eigendom) or G0B01A (Intellectual Property Management).

The student chooses at least 6 and at most 9 credits from the following list, taking into account that:- The course H04X2A (Project management) has to be taken up in the same year as the Master Thesis.- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H04B3A (Engels in de bedrijfsomgeving) or H04B4A (Frans in de bedrijfsomgeving).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H06B4A and H06U6A (Dutch Language and Culture).- Students may take maximum 9 credit points of the courses Industrial Experience, Industrial Internship, H0T39A Entrepreneurship in de praktijk/in practice and H0T91A Entrepreneurship in practice/service- learning.- Students select, with approval, at most one of the following two courses: H0T39A (Entrepreneurship in practice, 3 ECTS) and H0T91A (Entrepreneurship in practice/service-learning, 6 ECTS).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: C00M0A (Recht van de intellectuele eigendom) or G0B01A (Intellectual Property Management).

The student chooses at least 6 and at most 9 credits from the following list, taking into account that:- The course H04X2A (Project management) has to be taken up in the same year as the Master Thesis.- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H04B3A (Engels in de bedrijfsomgeving) or H04B4A (Frans in de bedrijfsomgeving).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: H06B4A and H06U6A (Dutch Language and Culture).- Students may take maximum 9 credit points of the courses Industrial Experience, Industrial Internship, H0T39A Entrepreneurship in de praktijk/in practice and H0T91A Entrepreneurship in practice/service- learning.- Students select, with approval, at most one of the following two courses: H0T39A (Entrepreneurship in practice, 3 ECTS) and H0T91A (Entrepreneurship in practice/service-learning, 6 ECTS).- A student can choose at most one of the following courses: C00M0A (Recht van de intellectuele eigendom) or G0B01A (Intellectual Property Management).

[CARD]
Quantum Physics
Students take a maximum of 16 credits.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will offer the students the necessary basis to disciplines (mathematics, physics, biology and electronics) in which they have had no training during their bachelor studies and which are essential for the rest of the master.The Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Fundamentals will be determined for each incoming student, based on his/her previous education. Once the fundamental courses are selected and approved they become compulsory for the master. If the students need less than 16 credits, the remaining credits can be chosen from the broadening elective courses.

pages.title: Master of Nanoscience, Nanotechnology and Nanoengineering (Programme for students started before 2025-2026) (Leuven) - Programme structure | KU Leuven

pages.content:
Upon enrolment, you receive an initial invoice for one academic year and based on 60 credits. 60 credits is the yearly standard amount of credits for most KU Leuven programmes. Please note this fee can differ between various programmes.
Here below, you can check the tuition fee for your particular situation for one academic year.
If you're obligated to enroll in a preparatory programme combined with your master programme, your intitial tuition fee will be based on a 60 credit calculation as well.
From mid-March onwards, tuition fees are recalculated based on the actual number of credits as approved in the Individual Study Programme (ISP). If you take up more or less than 60 credits, you may expect an additional invoice or a refund accordingly. More information about this subject can be found under 'Calculation'.
A separate fee calculation applies if you enroll for a combination of programmes, one of which is mentioned in the categories below:
Calculation
Tuition fee breakdown
Cost of living in Belgium
Tuition fee regulations
There might be scholarships and/or waivers available for you, please check the options here.
• advanced master programmes
• continuing education (including postgraduate programmes)
• doctoral programmes and other special registration categories
[CARD]

pages.content:
[HEADING] How to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder
[HEADING] Flemish degree holder
[HEADING] Dutch degree holder
[HEADING] Exceptions for Flemish degree holders
[HEADING] Others
[HEADING] Contact
You’ve made your choice for one of our programmes and want to apply. Great news! There are a few steps you need to take to start your application and the admission process at our university. The process will depend on if you've obtained your secondary education and/or previous degree(s) in the Flemish Community (Belgium) or not.
In case you did not obtain your previous degree(s) at an institution of the Flemish Community, you need to go through an admission process before you can register for a KU Leuven programme.
Apply as non-Flemish degree holder
Students who obtained a degree at an institution of the Flemish Community, can get direct access to their desired programme if their degree matches the intended study level. A secondary school degree gives access to the bachelor's programmes, the bachelor's degrees to the master's programmes.
If you are interested in the Bachelor of Business Engineering, the Bachelor of European Studies, or the Bachelor of Laws, then you will need to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder.
Register as Flemish degree holder
If you hold a Dutch VWO diploma ('voorbereidend wetenschappelijk onderwijs') and are interested in a bachelor's programme at KU Leuven, you have to follow the procedure for students with a degree obtained at an institution of the Flemish Community.
Information for Dutch degree holders (in Dutch)
If you hold another type of Dutch diploma, you have to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder.
Not all Flemish diplomas can be consulted via the Flemish learning and experience database (LED). This means that if your diploma is mentioned on the list, you must submit an application via Admissions to check wheter you can be admitted to the programme of your choice based on the diploma you have obtained.
Check out the list
For students who do not hold a secondary education diploma and want to study a bachelor's programme in Dutch or for strong students  in their final year of secondary education there are different procedures in place.
The KU Leuven Admissions Office functions as the contact, advice, expertise and administrative centre for KU Leuven and its Association with respect to the admission of students with a previous non-Flemish diploma.
• Procedure to register for a bachelor's degree in Dutch without a secondary education diploma (in Dutch)
• Project for cognitively strong  students in secondary school (in Dutch)
[GRID_TABLE]

Students who obtained a degree at an institution of the Flemish Community, can get direct access to their desired programme if their degree matches the intended study level. A secondary school degree gives access to the bachelor's programmes, the bachelor's degrees to the master's programmes.
If you are interested in the Bachelor of Business Engineering, the Bachelor of European Studies, or the Bachelor of Laws, then you will need to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder. 
Register as Flemish degree holder
Dutch degree holder
If you hold a Dutch VWO diploma ('voorbereidend wetenschappelijk onderwijs') and are interested in a bachelor's programme at KU Leuven, you have to follow the procedure for students with a degree obtained at an institution of the Flemish Community.
If you are interested in the Bachelor of Business Engineering, the Bachelor of European Studies, or the Bachelor of Laws, then you will need to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder. 
Information for Dutch degree holders (in Dutch)
If you hold another type of Dutch diploma, you have to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder.
[GRID_TABLE]
Exceptions for Flemish degree holders
Not all Flemish diplomas can be consulted via the Flemish learning and experience database (LED). This means that if your diploma is mentioned on the list, you must submit an application via Admissions to check wheter you can be admitted to the programme of your choice based on the diploma you have obtained.
Check out the list
Others
For students who do not hold a secondary education diploma and want to study a bachelor's programme in Dutch or for strong students  in their final year of secondary education there are different procedures in place.

Procedure to register for a bachelor's degree in Dutch without a secondary education diploma (in Dutch)
Project for cognitively strong  students in secondary school (in Dutch)
[CARD]
How to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder
In case you did not obtain your previous degree(s) at an institution of the Flemish Community, you need to go through an admission process before you can register for a KU Leuven programme.
Apply as non-Flemish degree holder
[CARD]
Flemish degree holder
Students who obtained a degree at an institution of the Flemish Community, can get direct access to their desired programme if their degree matches the intended study level. A secondary school degree gives access to the bachelor's programmes, the bachelor's degrees to the master's programmes.
If you are interested in the Bachelor of Business Engineering, the Bachelor of European Studies, or the Bachelor of Laws, then you will need to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder. 
Register as Flemish degree holder
[CARD]

If you are interested in the Bachelor of Business Engineering, the Bachelor of European Studies, or the Bachelor of Laws, then you will need to apply as a non-Flemish degree holder. 
Information for Dutch degree holders (in Dutch)

This means that if your diploma is mentioned on the list, you must submit an application via Admissions to check wheter you can be admitted to the programme of your choice based on the diploma you have obtained.
Check out the list
[CARD]
Others

Procedure to register for a bachelor's degree in Dutch without a secondary education diploma (in Dutch)
Project for cognitively strong  students in secondary school (in Dutch)
[CARD]
Contact
The KU Leuven Admissions Office functions as the contact, advice, expertise and administrative centre for KU Leuven and its Association with respect to the admission of students with a previous non-Flemish diploma.
Contact us

pages.content:
[HEADING] Prepare your application
[HEADING] Step-by-step guide to apply
[HEADING] Browse our programmes and get informed
[HEADING] Check admission requirements
[HEADING] Check the application window for your programme
[HEADING] Check the tuition fees and scholarship options for your programme
[HEADING] Collect the requested documents
[HEADING] Start your application
[HEADING] Exchange students
[HEADING] Credit contract
[HEADING] PhD students
[HEADING] Need help?
Interested in studying at KU Leuven?
This brief guide will explain all major steps you need to take to prepare your application in case you do not have a Flemish degree that gives direct access to your desired programme. Make sure you check all steps: it will significantly improve your chances to get admitted.
We look forward to receiving your application!
This guide will help you prepare your application if you wish to pursue a bachelor, master, advanced master or postgraduate studies at KU Leuven. There are different procedures for exchange students, PhD students or credit contracts.
For degree seeking students:
Every programme at KU Leuven has its own entry requirements, application procedure and deadlines. Please always consult the conditions specifically for your programme of interest.
First check whether KU Leuven offers any of the programmes you might be interested in. Our programme pages will give you details about the programme courses, further career opportunities and the student profile they're looking for.
Even with all the relevant information at hand, choosing a university can be a daunting task. Our international team is here to help you with a wide range of online presentations. You might even be able to meet us in your own country at one of the study abroad information fairs we attend.
Every KU Leuven programme has their own admission requirements. Make sure to read the detailed admission requirements of the specific study programmes available at the various KU Leuven campuses, to see if you are eligible.
Check the admission requirements
Search for your programme, click on 'admission requirements' and then select the admission requirements for the year that you would like to start your studies.
It is not possible to transfer into a programme at KU Leuven. Applicants interested in transferring must apply as a new student via the regular application procedure.
Our admissions process works on a rolling basis, but apply in time to start in the following academic year.
Some English programmes have a fixed deadline. You can check the specific deadline of your programme by using our application window tool.
For our Dutch programmes, there is a fixed deadline of February 1 for non-EEA applicants. For EEA applicants, there is no fixed deadline.
You can check the tuition fee and scholarship options for your programme using our tuition fee calculator and scholarships database.
All programmes request the same core documents. The additional documents depend on the programme you wish to apply for and can be consulted in the admission requirements.
To start your application at KU Leuven, log in to the web app via your browser and complete your personal data, upload the required documents and pay the application fee.
Application instructions
In general, it is not possible to submit an application for a diploma contract with the intention to start in the second semester. All students start the academic year in September. The only exception is the Preparatory programme for the Master of Rehabilitation Sciences and Physiotherapy, which always starts in February. All of our programmes are taught full time and during the day. We do not offer evening or weekend classes.
Check out the academic calendar
Exchange students remain enrolled at their home university while spending a few months to a full academic year at KU Leuven, free of charge. They take part in one of the European Commission’s educational programmes, such as Erasmus+. Others are visiting Leuven in the framework of an exchange agreement at faculty level between their home university and KU Leuven.
Apply as an exchange student
Some students just want to register for one or more course units, with the intention of obtaining a credit certificate instead of a full degree.
In their education regulations, the faculties determine what possible course credits can or cannot qualify for a credit contract.
Apply for a credit contract
You can start a PhD at KU Leuven either by applying for a vacant position or by finding a supervisor and writing your own research proposal.
Either way requires you to get a formal approval and invitation by your future supervisor.
Apply as a PhD student
Do you have questions or are you encountering any issues? Do not hesitate to reach out for help.
• Step 1: Browse our programmes and get informed
• Step 2: Check the admission requirements
• Step 3: Check the application window
• Step 4: Check the tuition fees and scholarship options for your programme
• Step 5: Collect the requested documents
• Step 6: Start your application
• Check our list of degree programmes
• Check our postgraduate certificates and continuing studies
• Join one of our webinars
• Meet us abroad

Start your application
To start your application at KU Leuven, log in to the web app via your browser and complete your personal data, upload the required documents and pay the application fee.
Application instructions
In general, it is not possible to submit an application for a diploma contract with the intention to start in the second semester. All students start the academic year in September. The only exception is the Preparatory programme for the Master of Rehabilitation Sciences and Physiotherapy, which always starts in February. All of our programmes are taught full time and during the day. We do not offer evening or weekend classes.
Check out the academic calendar
Exchange students
Exchange students remain enrolled at their home university while spending a few months to a full academic year at KU Leuven, free of charge. They take part in one of the European Commission’s educational programmes, such as Erasmus+. Others are visiting Leuven in the framework of an exchange agreement at faculty level between their home university and KU Leuven.
Apply as an exchange student
Credit contract
Some students just want to register for one or more course units, with the intention of obtaining a credit certificate instead of a full degree.
In their education regulations, the faculties determine what possible course credits can or cannot qualify for a credit contract.
Apply for a credit contract
PhD students
You can start a PhD at KU Leuven either by applying for a vacant position or by finding a supervisor and writing your own research proposal.
Either way requires you to get a formal approval and invitation by your future supervisor. 
Apply as a PhD student
[GRID_TABLE]
Prepare your application
Interested in studying at KU Leuven?
This brief guide will explain all major steps you need to take to prepare your application in case you do not have a Flemish degree that gives direct access to your desired programme. Make sure you check all steps: it will significantly improve your chances to get admitted.
We look forward to receiving your application!






Step-by-step guide to apply
This guide will help you prepare your application if you wish to pursue a bachelor, master, advanced master or postgraduate studies at KU Leuven. There are different procedures for exchange students, PhD students or credit contracts.
For degree seeking students:

Step 1: Browse our programmes and get informed
Step 2: Check the admission requirements
Step 3: Check the application window
Step 4: Check the tuition fees and scholarship options for your programme
Step 5: Collect the requested documents
Step 6: Start your application

Every programme at KU Leuven has its own entry requirements, application procedure and deadlines. Please always consult the conditions specifically for your programme of interest.






 




1

Browse our programmes and get informed
First check whether KU Leuven offers any of the programmes you might be interested in. Our programme pages will give you details about the programme courses, further career opportunities and the student profile they're looking for. 
Even with all the relevant information at hand, choosing a university can be a daunting task. Our international team is here to help you with a wide range of online presentations. You might even be able to meet us in your own country at one of the study abroad information fairs we attend. 

Check our list of degree programmes
Check our postgraduate certificates and continuing studies
Join one of our webinars
Meet us abroad










 




2

Check admission requirements
Every KU Leuven programme has their own admission requirements. Make sure to read the detailed admission requirements of the specific study programmes available at the various KU Leuven campuses, to see if you are eligible. 
Check the admission requirements
Search for your programme, click on 'admission requirements' and then select the admission requirements for the year that you would like to start your studies.
It is not possible to transfer into a programme at KU Leuven. Applicants interested in transferring must apply as a new student via the regular application procedure.









 




3

Check the application window for your programme
Our admissions process works on a rolling basis, but apply in time to start in the following academic year.
Some English programmes have a fixed deadline. You can check the specific deadline of your programme by using our application window tool.
For our Dutch programmes, there is a fixed deadline of February 1 for non-EEA applicants. For EEA applicants, there is no fixed deadline.









 




4

Check the tuition fees and scholarship options for your programme
You can check the tuition fee and scholarship options for your programme using our tuition fee calculator and scholarships database.

Tuition fee calculator
Scholarships database










 




5

Collect the requested documents
All programmes request the same core documents. The additional documents depend on the programme you wish to apply for and can be consulted in the admission requirements.

Application for a Bachelor's programme
Application for a Master's , Advanced Master's or postgraduate programme










 




6

Start your application
To start your application at KU Leuven, log in to the web app via your browser and complete your personal data, upload the required documents and pay the application fee.
Application instructions







In general, it is not possible to submit an application for a diploma contract with the intention to start in the second semester. All students start the academic year in September. The only exception is the Preparatory programme for the Master of Rehabilitation Sciences and Physiotherapy, which always starts in February. All of our programmes are taught full time and during the day. We do not offer evening or weekend classes.
Check out the academic calendar


 






Exchange students
Exchange students remain enrolled at their home university while spending a few months to a full academic year at KU Leuven, free of charge. They take part in one of the European Commission’s educational programmes, such as Erasmus+. Others are visiting Leuven in the framework of an exchange agreement at faculty level between their home university and KU Leuven.
Apply as an exchange student






Credit contract
Some students just want to register for one or more course units, with the intention of obtaining a credit certificate instead of a full degree.
In their education regulations, the faculties determine what possible course credits can or cannot qualify for a credit contract.
Apply for a credit contract






PhD students
You can start a PhD at KU Leuven either by applying for a vacant position or by finding a supervisor and writing your own research proposal.
Either way requires you to get a formal approval and invitation by your future supervisor. 
Apply as a PhD student






 

Need help?
Do you have questions or are you encountering any issues? Do not hesitate to reach out for help.
Contact us

pages.content:
[HEADING] On KU Leuven Career Zone
[HEADING] Want to get everything out of KU Leuven Career Zone?
[HEADING] Through your student association or faculty
[HEADING] For employers
Find your student job, volunteer work, internship or entry-level job on KU Leuven Career Zone
Use KU Leuven Career Zone on your phone too!
Find your job
KU Leuven Career Zone is always accessible, from the start of your studies up to two years after graduation. The platform is open to all KU Leuven students and PhD students on all campuses, as well as to students at UCLL (Leuven-Diest) and LUCA School of Arts Lemmens Campus looking for a student job.
Discover our tips & tricks
Testimonial Benjamin
Looking for a job related to your specialisation? Student associations and faculties often offer specific internships and entry-level jobs.
They also provide lots of information on opportunities after graduation, career paths and the alumni network.
Do you want to advertise jobs to students or recent graduates?
Discover the options for employers
• Flexibly filter according to your preferences
• Search the extensive database for jobs in Belgium and abroad
• Find a job that suits you
• Attend job events
• Check out the opportunities for graduating students and alumni
• Find your faculty's internship website (overview in Dutch)
[GRID_TABLE]

Discover our tips & tricks
Testimonial Benjamin
Through your student association or faculty
Looking for a job related to your specialisation? Student associations and faculties often offer specific internships and entry-level jobs.
They also provide lots of information on opportunities after graduation, career paths and the alumni network.

Check out the opportunities for graduating students and alumni
Find your faculty's internship website (overview in Dutch)
For employers
Do you want to advertise jobs to students or recent graduates?
Discover the options for employers
[GRID_TABLE]
On KU Leuven Career Zone
Find your student job, volunteer work, internship or entry-level job on KU Leuven Career Zone

Flexibly filter according to your preferences
Search the extensive database for jobs in Belgium and abroad
Find a job that suits you
Attend job events

[HEADING] Leaving?
You can check the tuition fee for your programme for the current and next academic year using our tuition fee calculator.
Consult your tuition fee
Need financial support to finance your studies or looking for a tuition fee waiver?
Check out our options
Registrations that are not tied to the number of study points pay a different tuition fee.
These regulations establish the principles of tuition fees for all persons that are registered as students at KU Leuven or participate in a programme or activity organised by KU Leuven.
Tuition fee regulations
Do you have any more questions?
Tel. +32 (0)16 32 40 00
Consult the Application website
Upon registration you receive an invoice with a due date of two weeks. The payment is not possible in cash or by creditcard.
Your tuition fee depends on the type of contract you sign up for and the number of study points you take as part of your programme.
Calculation of tuition fee
There can be some financial consequences to terminating or changing your studies.
Consequences of terminating/changing your studies
